summary: This FBI document details an investigation into Alfredo Rodriguez, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, who attempted to sell documents related to a civil lawsuit against Epstein to attorney Bradley Edwards for $50,000. Edwards, representing four female plaintiffs, had already deposed Rodriguez and served him with a subpoena. The FBI authorized a sting operation using an Undercover Employee (UCE) to record Rodriguez and complete the transaction, citing potential obstruction of justice.

persons.name: Bradley James Edwards
persons.role: Attorney representing plaintiffs in civil suit against Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Attorney who was contacted by Alfredo Rodriguez attempting to sell documents related to the Epstein case. He informed Rodriguez the demand was illegal and cooperated with the FBI in a sting operation.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: Former Epstein employee who contacted attorney Bradley Edwards in August 2009, attempting to sell documents pertinent to the civil case against Epstein for $50,000, despite being under subpoena to provide them.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual being sued in a civil case by four female individuals represented by Bradley Edwards. His former employee, Alfredo Rodriguez, possessed documents related to this case.

connections.description: Edwards, as an attorney in a civil suit against Epstein, deposed and subpoenaed Rodriguez. Rodriguez then contacted Edwards to illegally sell the subpoenaed documents.
Rodriguez is identified as a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein.
Edwards is the attorney representing four female plaintiffs in a civil lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Rodriguez contacts Edwards to sell documents
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez contacted attorney Bradley Edwards and offered to sell documents related to the Jeffrey Epstein civil case for $50,000.

events.title: FBI authorizes undercover sting operation
events.description: The FBI authorized a consensual monitoring operation where an Undercover Employee (UCE) would be introduced by Edwards to Rodriguez to complete the document transaction and gather evidence.

keyFacts: A former Jeffrey Epstein employee, Alfredo Rodriguez, attempted to illegally sell case-related documents to plaintiffs' attorney Bradley Edwards for $50,000 in August 2009, despite being under a federal subpoena to provide them.
Attorney Bradley Edwards, representing four female plaintiffs suing Epstein, reported the attempted sale to the FBI and cooperated in a sting operation.
The FBI authorized a 90-day operation using an Undercover Employee (UCE), body recorders, and CCTV to gather evidence against Rodriguez for potential obstruction of justice.
The document indicates the investigation was not triggered by a request from a high-ranking DOJ official, member of Congress, judge, or executive branch official.
The potential charges considered against Rodriguez included obstruction of justice under U.S. Code Title 18, Sections 1509 and 1510.
